awd_titl_txt: TWC: TTP Option: Small: Collaborative: Integrated Smart Grid Analytics for Anomaly Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
The modernized electric grid, the Smart Grid, integrates two-way communication technologies across power generation, transmission and distribution, in order to deliver electricity efficiently, securely and cost-effectively. On the monitoring and control side, it employs real-time monitoring offered by a messaging-based advanced metering infrastructure (AMI), which ensures the grid's stability and reliability, as well as the efficient implementation of demand response schemes to mitigate bursts demand. The efficient implementation of these features presents a number of challenges, but also opportunities for technology development in engineering, networking, and data analytics.

The intellectual contributions include the development of a framework that encompasses fast signal processing and machine learning algorithms, together with multi-sensor information to assess the health of the network. Specifically, the study will investigate algorithms for adaptive detection over streaming, high-dimensional and potentially missing value data. Furthermore, the project, via industry collaborators and power provisioners, will provide a comprehensive empirical evaluation with real-world data; this includes an open-source proof-of-concept prototype for quickly inferring nefarious activity in home-area networks, and a cloud-based testbed for examining realistic scenarios in a wide-area setting.

por.por_cntn:
The modernized electric network, i.e., the "smart grid", introduces two-way communication capabilities within its distribution and transmission system, aiming in advancing the network's reliability, safety, security and sustainability. However, the integration of bidirectional communication ends the grid's isolation and expands its attack surface, exposing the system to an array of cyber-security threats. For example, nefarious actors can manipulate or spoof the data transmitted within a transmission network (e.g., data that includes important network measurements such as power injection or power flow within the grid), aiming at compromising the grid's "state estimation" process. These data-driven attacks, termed as "false data injection (FDI)", require some level of sophistication on behalf of the offenders, but once executed can inflict acute and instantaneous damage in the grid's stability and performance. One can envision scenarios of attackers equipped with 1) knowledge regarding the network's topology and transmission line characteristics and 2) the ability to physically access a handful of insecure smart grid measurement units, thus being capable of compiling attack vectors that would derail the system's stable operation.

 

It is, therefore, imperative to ensure that malicious activity is detected and reported rapidly. In this project, we examined statistical and machine learning techniques for the detection of false data injection attacks in smart grids. We examined frameworks that can help tackle the problem from the perspective of "home-area network" monitoring, as well as through the lens of "wide-area network" monitoring. For the former, we studied a measurement-based situation awareness framework that integrates evidence from sensors (e.g., ambient temperature and motion/activity sensors) within home-area networks, and aims at inferring anomalies that would signify a coordinated, well-orchestrated attack on residential smart meters at increasing spatial scales. By leveraging multi-view sensor readings, we developed a Bayesian-based correlative monitoring approach that could quickly detect power shifts to anomalous regimes. As part of the "transition-to-practice" component of this project, the proposed framework was implemented using off-the-shelf, accessible components, such as Raspberry Pi's and ZWave-based wireless sensors, and a working prototype was robustly evaluated at a next-generation "smart-home" environment of a partnering institution.  

 

For "wide-area network" monitoring, we proposed a framework that employed measurements from trusted (secure) nodes in order to detect abnormal "spoofing" activity on other nodes, possibly tampered. Our model considered the structural similarities in the electricity consumption reported by the network's smart meters, and exploited the spatial correlation thereof (via a statistical technique known as "network kriging"). To alleviate the large-dimensionality aspect of the problem at hand, the meters were clustered into classes of similar energy patterns. We evaluated our algorithms using real-world building data obtained from a large university campus. For the scenario in which the assumption on the subset of "trusted" nodes is unrealistic, we explored several statistical spatio-temporal models for efficient diagnosis of FDI attacks that borrow strength from historical observations in order to identify state abnormalities. The proposed methods leverage the data co-linearities that naturally arise in electric network measurements to provide forecasts for the network's "step-ahead" measurement state, aiming to quickly detect the presence of "bad data". We evaluated the proposed approaches with data infused with stealth attacks constructed via three different attack strategies. Further, we juxtaposed our algorithms against two other forecasting-aided detection methods appearing in the literature, and discussed the trade-offs of all techniques when applied on real-world power grid data.

 

Overall, this project aimed at balancing the tactical asymmetry between network adversaries (i.e., nefarious users or nation states) and defenders of critical infrastructure (i.e., security engineers and utility operators), by providing the latter with new statistical techniques, and their open-source software implementation, for rapid diagnosis of erroneous electric grid behavior. Towards this objective, it provided unique professional development opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students, from diverse societal backgrounds, in fields that lie at the intersection of computer science, network security, statistics and engineering.
